If I am a lawyer, how should I avoid vio:
As a law-abiding professional, adhering to professional ethical standards is important for maintaining public trust. In most jurisdictions, lawyers are required to adhere to a set of professional standards known as the Model Rules of Professional Conduct for Legal Professionals. These rules include rules such as Rule 1.5 which requires lawyers not to engage in fraudulent or deceitful activities in the pursuit of their legal services. By abiding by the rules and guidelines established by the bar associations at your location, you are demonstrating strong legal professionalism and upholding the integrity of the legal profession. 

 
 
 
 
You may also want to look into professional continuing legal education (CLE) programs to make sure you stay up to date on changes in the rules and industry best practices. Additionally, it may be wise to check the advice of colleagues, a supervising attorney or an ethics committee if you’re questioning specific conduct that you believe violates rules or guidelines. In most circumstances, there is good reason for a lawyer to confront another lawyer about suboptimal conduct, but it is also important to respect the other side’s right to defend any decisions they made regarding what should or should not have happened.
